Award.AwardTitle: CC*IIE Networking Infrastructure: SciNet: A ScienceDMZ for Science and Engineering Research at University of Puerto Rico Mayaguez

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The SciNet Project at the University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez (UPRM) seeks to build an advanced networking infrastructure to support science and engineering research. SciNet is a high-speed, frictionless Science DMZ network, designed to interconnect computer clusters, storage systems, gene sequencers, oceanographic sensors, and other scientific instruments available at UPRM. Modern research efforts depend upon readily access to computers and scientific instruments to help scientists analyze data resulting from their experiments. The computer network has emerged as the system bottleneck in this infrastructure due to current bandwidth limitations. The Science DMZ model has emerged as a solution to this problem by providing a secure, high-speed, frictionless, separate network segment that is dedicated exclusively to science traffic.

SciNet consists of six points of access (PoAs) strategically located at the buildings housing researchers performing data intensive work in gene sequencing, high-energy physics, computational chemistry, fluid mechanics, oceanography, bioinformatics, networking, and big data analytics. Each PoA consists of a networking switch, high-speed storage equipment, and monitoring tools to ensure proper operation. SciNet is designed to accept additional PoAs and be peered with the Science DMZ of another institution. Thus, it enables collaborators from other institutions to access the infrastructure available at UPRM. Therefore, SciNet is a key enabler to help faculty and students at UPRM, which is a Hispanic-serving institution, become involved in national research initiatives, particularly in fields of high societal impacts such as genetics, energy, environmental sciences, and computer technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

The SciNet Project at the University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez (UPRM) built an advanced networking infrastructure to support science and engineering research. SciNet is a high-speed, firewall-less Science DMZ network, designed to interconnect computer clusters, storage systems, gene sequencers, oceanographic sensors, and other scientific instruments available at UPRM. Modern research efforts depend upon readily access to computers and scientific instruments to help scientists analyze data resulting from their experiments.   Unfortunately, the computer network is becoming the weakest link in this infrastructure due to bandwidth limitations imposed by firewalls and other security policies. The Science DMZ model has emerged as a solution to this problem by providing a secure, high-speed, firewall-less, separate network segment that is dedicated exclusively to science traffics. 

SciNet consists of six points of access (PoAs) strategically located at the buildings housing researchers performing data-intensive work in gene sequencing, high-energy physics, computational chemistry, fluid mechanics, oceanography, bioinformatics, networking, and big data analytics. Each PoA consists of a networking switch, high-speed storage equipment, and monitoring tools to ensure proper operation. 

SciNet is designed to accept additional PoAs and be peered with the Science DMZ of another institution. Thus, it enables collaborators from other institutions to access the infrastructure available at UPRM. Therefore, SciNet is a key enabler to help faculty and students at UPRM, which is a Hispanic-serving institution, become involved in national research initiatives, particularly in fields of high societal impacts such as genetics, energy, environmental sciences, and computer technology.

New UPR System Network

The UPR System will move to a new high-speed WAN for the summer of 2019. The new network provider is Claro, an international telecommunications company. Under the new network design, there will be a 10 Gbps external link between the graduate campuses: Mayaguez, Rio Piedras, Medical Sciences, and Central Administration/High-Performance Facility. There will also be a 100Gpbs link to Internet 2. It is important to notice that at the beginning of this project,  back in 2014, increasing the bandwidth between campuses was not a priority of the UPR Administration. The key triggers to accomplish this institutional change have been the deployment of Science DMZ networks at UPRM and UPR Rio Piedras. 

Movement of clusters

The various clusters and other computational assets have begun to move to SciNet. The High Energy Physics Group moved its cluster, and instantly observed great bandwidth improvements. In particular, the bandwidth improved from no more than 20Mbytes/sec to over 40Mbytes/sec with peaks of 60Mbytes/sec.

 

SciNet Launch

On April 13, 2018, we made the official launch of the SciNet network to the UPRM community. Figure 3 shows the PI, Manuel Rodriguez-Martinez, discussing with the Director of the UPRM Computer Center. There is a youtube video on the following link : https://youtu.be/3Q7LMh52Bkc

 There is also a press release (in Spanish) here: 

http://admin.uprm.edu/portada/article.php?id=4171

 Big Data Analytics course

The PI has developed a new course in Big Data Analytics, leveraging on the experience obtained while installing big data tools to support our research team. The course was offered for the second time during the fall of 2018. The web site of the course is: 

https://sites.google.com/a/upr.edu/big-data-fall-2018/ 

The Big Data Analytics course given to a group of thirty (30) seniors/graduate students from the Computer Science and Computer Engineering programs at UPRM. Topics included the use of Science DMZ networks to support data analytics between science teams located in wide area networks.
